newsitem.title: USA: Public divided over tobacco immunity - poll.
newsitem.headline: Public divided over tobacco immunity - poll.

text.p: Most Americans think cigarette makers lied about the risks of smoking and about half feel the companies should not be given immunity from future legal claims, a poll said Friday.

As negotiations continue between state and tobacco industry officials over a settlement of claims against cigarette makers, the poll conducted for Business Week magazine found that 49 percent thought cigarette makers should not get immunity from legal claims.
Forty-five percent thought cigarette makers should be granted immunity.

The poll found that 71 percent thought tobacco companies lied about the health risks of smoking cigarettes, while 23 percent said the companies told the truth. Six percent said they did not know or refused to answer.

When asked if tobacco companies tell the truth about the addictive qualities of cigarettes, 77 percent of those polled thought the tobacco companies lied. Another 15 percent said the companies told the truth.
The poll was conducted June 6-10 and has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.
